content.description:
Start sittingÂ under the overhang with a small crimp for the left hand and a pocket of your choosing for the right. Work your way into Texas Two Step.

Adds a couple of tenuous moves in lieu of the reachy span of the original. Much better flow.
content.location: Two feet right of the start of Texas Two Step.

content.description:
Start with your left on on an obvious jug and your right on a very low pocket.  Figure a way to throw your right up to a sloper jug.  From there, find anything you can with your left to finish the problem.

This problem was FA'd in the early 2000's, and since the start is at the bottom of a small cataract, there is a chance the dirt has eroded from around the bottom of the problem.  In any case, the problem could may be a little different from how it was first sent, so take the grade with a grain of salt.
content.protection: A pad.  The problem starts under a dry cataract, so the dirt is soft under the problem.
content.location: Starts just to the right of Mr. Prefontaine.  Your left uses the same start hold that Mr. Prefontaine uses as its right start hold.

content.description:
Sit start with your left on a shallow pocket and your right in an obvious in-cut jug handle--though it will not feel like a jug when used on this problem.  Upgrade your left, pick the tenuous feet you like best, then deadpoint up to your choice of a shallow dimple or a pretty bad sloper.  Continue up the prow and top out by moving right onto the slab face.

Compression is the name of the game.
content.protection: Pads.  The landing is pretty flat.
content.location: This climbs the prow pointing into the creek bed.
